Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: It’s Thursday evening, and my phone buzzes with a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” Every week, I check in, tell them about my life, and listen to their stories. They wait for my call, and I know how much it means to them. But tonight, the office is tense. It’s the last day of the quarter, and my manager’s voice echoes in my head: “We need five more sales to hit target. No one leaves until we do.” My headset feels heavy. I glance at the clock—7:00 p.m.—the time I usually call home. My parents will be waiting, probably sitting by the phone, expecting to hear my voice. But my team is counting on me, too. If I step away, I might miss a sale, and everyone’s bonus is on the line. My heart pounds as I stare at my phone, torn between dialing home and making another sales call, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in.
